item.title:
China won't endorse Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine, but it won’t condemn it either. Whose side is China really on, and what does its stance mean for global order?
The Economist’s Beijing bureau chief, David Rennie, explains https://t.co/N7BBjuUmSH

Vladimir Putin “props up” Alexander Lukashenko’s regime, says @Tsihanouskaya. “The West’s weakness has led to Belarus becoming an accomplice in the most brutal European conflict since the second world war” https://t.co/Vx0qS3XQPF
Russia is pivoting largely because the first phase of its war has been a failure https://t.co/Ya3fw1D6p5

We’re hiring interns to cover foreign affairs. If you have a boundless curiosity about the world and can write about it concisely, wittily and with analytical rigour, we’d like to hear from you https://t.co/JkK5978xln
Countries are rushing to add military capacity https://t.co/tMMqOzYxLu

"The fate of both Belarus & Ukraine is at stake. Belarus can't be free without a free Ukraine & vice versa. Dismantling Lukashenka's dictatorship would help 🇺🇦 win the war". Read my latest article on the crisis in the region at @TheEconomist. https://t.co/Lu0pSZrjh0
The idea that Russia was only ever interested in Donbas is nonsense https://t.co/1mwTCyqHj6
The invasion of Ukraine looks like a turning-point in the fortunes of far-right groups https://t.co/Wa7OohaQis

Whether Vladimir Putin succeeds in snuffing out Ukraine will depend not just on Ukrainians’ astonishing courage, but on the West’s continued determination to give it the help that it needs https://t.co/Ys9kNdJG6j

Andrei Kozyrev believes the prospect of a westernising, democratic and prosperous Ukraine is the nightmare of the Putin regime. “It will be a powerful motivation for Russians to follow suit,” the former Russian foreign minister writes https://t.co/YMlRiwqb1s
“What does a Ukrainian victory look like?” we asked Volodymyr Zelensky. “Victory is being able to save as many lives as possible,” he said https://t.co/XJ6oNtwqnQ
Ukrainian defenders have been sharing known military frequencies, recording Russian communications and uploading them for volunteers to parse for information https://t.co/4nmRStQBUA
“Ukraine needs to stand and survive,” says Volodymyr Zelensky’s chief of staff in an interview with The Economist. “If it doesn’t, Putin will never stop” https://t.co/OLMQjF2sAm
Radios may be less lethal than weapons, but Russia’s failure to invest in communications is hobbling its forces https://t.co/pryDSmqxgY
In an unholy alliance, it is helping Vladimir Putin to justify his war at home https://t.co/RtEnf2L1RB
The Kremlin faces an unappetising choice. It can have the southern city of Mariupol—or it can have an economy https://t.co/IiZv3DwnTQ

The West should keep the bulk of its sanctions in place and maintain its military preparedness “until the Kremlin respects the rights of its people, and of those in other countries”, writes Russia’s former foreign minister in a guest essay https://t.co/GaDqd8iIWR

Volodymyr Zelensky uses his interview with The Economist to issue an urgent call for better weapons from NATO, warning that “the Russians have thousands of military vehicles, and they are coming and coming and coming” https://t.co/wetnU8Wd79

“There is a risk in providing assistance…but there is also a risk in not acting robustly enough, because Vladimir Putin is a man who only understands strength.” Marie Yovanovitch, America’s former ambassador to Ukraine, talks to “The Economist Asks” https://t.co/uLHNCyQpZn
Ukrainian mayors are leading by example in the war against Russia – and they’re doing a good job of it. From @1843mag https://t.co/GOd60ef3bl

“If the Kremlin gets away with this war, and business relations return to normal in its aftermath, the country’s aggression will continue to grow—with or without Vladimir Putin,” Russia’s former foreign minister warns https://t.co/58tYN88v6T

“If Vladimir Putin wants to recreate the Soviet Union, he’s doing a great job of it in Russia...the stock market’s been closed, the rouble’s worth a penny.” Marie Yovanovitch, America’s former ambassador to Ukraine, on “The Economist Asks” https://t.co/xzk2fx2e7D
He divides NATO into four camps, praises America and Britain, and says Germany is trying to strike a balance between Russia and Ukraine https://t.co/mHadZ8UtdC
Ukrainian defenders have been sharing known military frequencies, recording Russian communications and uploading them for volunteers to parse for information https://t.co/Y6peVJbwuY

On the embargo on oil and gas that has been discussed but so far not implemented by Europe, he says: “We are hearing that the decision depends on whether Russia launches a chemical attack on us. This is not the right approach. We are not guinea pigs” https://t.co/ks3EyaWpeB

Vladimir Putin is a “thug”, says Mikhail Khodorkovsky, a former oil mogul and political prisoner. The West must face him down now or prepare for something worse, he warns in a guest essay for The Economist https://t.co/0ymkFZ4tZ1
Russian planes were dropping 100 bombs a day on Mariupol. But inside the neoclassical theatre it felt safe – until it too was blown apart https://t.co/2YjqeALu2a

“It's not about being brave or not,” the president says. “I have to act the way I do...you have to be honest, so that people believe you. You don’t need to try. You need to be yourself” https://t.co/gbnLMNEtJX
Many Russian forces are communicating on unencrypted high-frequency channels that allow anyone with a ham radio to eavesdrop https://t.co/ascjZj4j29
Ramzan Kadyrov’s men appear to have fared no better than the rest of the Russian forces https://t.co/pPy1Jy9aMY

Volodymyr Zelensky uses his interview with The Economist to issue an urgent call for better weapons from NATO, warning that “the Russians have thousands of military vehicles, and they are coming and coming and coming” https://t.co/KHZSZUXK0d

Ukrainians want to embrace the values held dear by other European nations. Alexei Navalny, the jailed leader of Russia’s opposition, wants the same for his country. Vladimir Putin cannot face either desire https://t.co/7c3UHnIrkK
“I didn’t expect it to be this hard,” he says in an exclusive interview. “You can’t imagine what it means or how well you’ll do as president.” Inside Ukraine’s situation room https://t.co/GjZ4e5RwEV
In theory, the Academy Awards celebrate the art and craft of film-making. They did a woeful job of that this year https://t.co/1tY3XY1VY3

Speaking to The Economist in a government building fortified with sandbags and surrounded with tank traps, Ukraine’s president was disarmingly authentic and humane. Read our exclusive interview https://t.co/ieGO8rW16h
One of the many surprising failures of the Russian invasion force in Ukraine has been in radio communications https://t.co/o7BzR2W92I
“Welcome to the fortress.” Meeting the president, deep in the body of Ukraine’s war machine https://t.co/9OJgP9mlPj

Vladimir Putin “is throwing Russian soldiers like logs into a train’s furnace. What is more, they don't even bother burying them,” says Ukraine’s president in an exclusive interview https://t.co/h2br5luI9J
Though he is tired, and fidgets endlessly, there is a calmness beneath the swagger. Meeting Ukraine's president in his “fortress” in Kyiv https://t.co/kHopyDZuQr
Kazakhstan has long cultivated warm relations with Russia. But it is watching Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine with apprehension verging on horror https://t.co/eP9lPIclSC
In an exclusive interview he divides NATO into four camps, praises America and Britain, and says Germany is trying to strike a balance between Russia and Ukraine https://t.co/wexKgza5Tm
Russia must be recognised for what it is: “a nation under a belligerent and ruthless dictatorship”, argues @andreivkozyrev in a guest essay for The Economist https://t.co/Nxu63cwCvd

Speaking to The Economist in a government building fortified with sandbags and surrounded with tank traps, Ukraine’s president was disarmingly authentic and humane. Read our exclusive interview https://t.co/CJ1yitpetd
Squinting, you can see the snipers: left, right, up and down. The air-defence systems, huge chunks of metal, are easier to spot. It was time to meet the president https://t.co/BaX7x2K156

Darkened night trains and layer upon layer of security: on “The Intelligence” our editors describe how they travelled to Volodymyr Zelensky’s “fortress” for an exclusive interview with Ukraine’s president https://t.co/GpHy6GDn1r
Ukraine’s closest neighbours are already feeling strained: Moldova is overwhelmed and parts of Poland are buckling. For economies, refugees could be both a burden and a boon https://t.co/5UsjCffzgx
The number fleeing Ukraine will soon exceed 4m—but that does not count those displaced within the country. Nearly a quarter of the population has been forced to move https://t.co/SaHHUy93tV
Russian-speaking cities expected Putin’s mercy. Instead he is destroying them https://t.co/KD3wYOMD6m
“I don’t think Putin has been a bunker for two weeks or six months, but for more like two decades,” says Ukraine’s president https://t.co/TkuwPzXOAH
Vladimir Putin’s war threatens not only Ukraine’s future, but Russia’s too https://t.co/2pp4PWIITa
